Oedema is defined as the visible or palpable accumulation of fluid in the interstitial tissue.

A distinction must be made between :

* oedema caused locally by inflammation, venous or lymphatic insufficiency;
* generalised oedema resulting from a positive sodium and water balance (extracellular hyperhydration). In the most severe forms, this is known as hydrops.

question.title: What is the definition of oedema?
question.description: Oedema is defined as the visible or palpable accumulation of fluid in the interstitial tissue. What is the main cause of oedema?

option_a.title: Inflammation, venous or lymphatic insufficiency
option_a.description: Oedema caused by local inflammation or circulatory problems

option_b.title: Generalised oedema resulting from a positive sodium and water balance
option_b.description: Oedema caused by excess sodium and water in the body

option_c.title: Hydrops, a severe form of generalised oedema
option_c.description: A specific type of generalised oedema that is severe

option_d.title: Oedema caused by a positive potassium and water balance
option_d.description: Oedema caused by excess potassium and water in the body

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The first letter of the correct option
